result.execSummary:
The defendant Anthony Trice was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Causing Mental Harm to Child, a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.04(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS NOT eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program but 
IS eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
*11 months credit for time served - 335 days

superMiscConds.notes:
Court costs and DNA costs to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision.

If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.
Submit to an AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.

Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling by Agent.
No contact with the victim or her family members.
No unsupervised contact with anyone under the age of 18 years old.
Provide DNA sample if not previously done.
Register as a Sex Offender during his duration of supervision.
Agent to determine if he is to be supervised as a sex offender.

Summary of Pleas agreement and defendant's sentencing recommendation
with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Anthony  Trice in court, in custody, with attorney Samuel W. Benedict.   Ted Szczupakiewicz appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant enters a no contest plea to the charge in the amended information. Court imposed the following sentence:

  The Defendant was sentenced to the following:

IMPOSED SENTENCE of: 

8 YEARS IMPRISONMENT (CREDIT -  11 months credit, 0 days)
  -  3 1/2  YEAR(S) OF INITIAL CONFINEMENT
  - 4 1/2  YEAR(S) OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION;

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION:  
*AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended;
*Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
*No contact with the victim or her family members
*No unsupervised contact with anyone under the age of 18 years old
*DNA sample to be provided if not yet previously done.
*Register as sex offender during his duration of supervision
*Agent to determine if he is to be supervised as a sex offender
 
COURT COSTS:  $268.00 (to be paid as a condition of extended supervision);

DNA SURCHARGE $250.00 (to be paid as a condition of extended supervision)
 
Defendant is not eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant is eligible for Substance Abuse Program.

Felony warnings, voting rights and firearms warnings given.

Defendant Anthony Trice in court, in custody, with attorney Samuel W. Benedict.   Ted Szczupakiewicz appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Case called for Motion to Suppress Statements.  Officer Ken Stucker was sworn and testified on behalf of the State. State presents exhibit #1 marked and #2 marked and received. Cross examination by the defense. Redirect by the state. Re cross by the defense. Parties have rested. Defense makes a brief argument. State makes a brief arguments. Court to review the whole DVD
 and present oral ruling. Any briefs to be filed by 03/01/2016.  Bail remains as fixed.  Oral ruling scheduled for April 6, 2016 at 02:30 pm.  Jury trial - 12 person scheduled for May 10, 2016 at 08:30 am.  Jury status hearing scheduled for May 5, 2016 at 08:30 am.
